values.description:
Generate and install a cmake version file. This wold allow the clients of gazebo to do:

```
find_package(gazebo 4.0)
```

and using the SameMajorVersion compatibility, all version 4.X where X equal or greater than 0 should work.
values.title: Generate a cmake version file (issue #1226)

summary.raw:
Generate and install a cmake version file. This wold allow the clients of gazebo to do:

```
find_package(gazebo 4.0)
```

and using the SameMajorVersion compatibility, all version 4.X where X equal or greater than 0 should work.

and using the SameMajorVersion compatibility, all version 4.X where X equal or greater than 0 should work.

values.description:
The EXAMPLE_* test was failing to build these plugins on OSX. It was failing to link to sdformat, protobuf, and boost. Using `find_package` instead of `pkg_check_modules` was sufficient to fix linking to sdformat and protobuf, but I had to do a separate `find_package(Boost)`.

UPDATE: see the console output of [this jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-homebrew-amd64/90/testReport/) to see the failures.
values.title: Fix build for two example plugins on osx

summary.raw:
The EXAMPLE_* test was failing to build these plugins on OSX. It was failing to link to sdformat, protobuf, and boost. Using `find_package` instead of `pkg_check_modules` was sufficient to fix linking to sdformat and protobuf, but I had to do a separate `find_package(Boost)`.

UPDATE: see the console output of [this jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-homebrew-amd64/90/testReport/) to see the failures.
summary.html:
The EXAMPLE_* test was failing to build these plugins on OSX. It was failing to link to sdformat, protobuf, and boost. Using find_package instead of pkg_check_modules was sufficient to fix linking to sdformat and protobuf, but I had to do a separate find_package(Boost).

UPDATE: see the console output of this jenkins job to see the failures.

values.description:
Allows to spawn multiple models by specifying its region, distribution and number of objects.

It requires [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/112) sdformat pull request.

**Known limitations:**

* The objects can collide each other when using a random distribution. 
* There are different alternatives for specifying the position of the models, but nothing is ready to specify orientations.

**Open question:** The Population class needs a pointer to the world and access to the private `rootElement` class member. This is required for spawning the models without using the transport. I included Population as a friend class inside the World class but I'm open for suggestions (create a public accessor to `rootElement`, use the transport for spawning models).

**Update**: Solved using `InsertModelString()`

**Update**: A new tutorial has been created [here](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/32/new-tutorial-for-model-population).

![gazebo_population.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/98514253-gazebo_population.png)
values.title: Automatic model population

summary.raw:
Allows to spawn multiple models by specifying its region, distribution and number of objects.

It requires [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/112) sdformat pull request.

**Known limitations:**

* The objects can collide each other when using a random distribution. 
* There are different alternatives for specifying the position of the models, but nothing is ready to specify orientations.

**Open question:** The Population class needs a pointer to the world and access to the private `rootElement` class member. This is required for spawning the models without using the transport. I included Population as a friend class inside the World class but I'm open for suggestions (create a public accessor to `rootElement`, use the transport for spawning models).

**Update**: Solved using `InsertModelString()`

**Update**: A new tutorial has been created [here](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/32/new-tutorial-for-model-population).

![gazebo_population.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/98514253-gazebo_population.png)
summary.html:
Allows to spawn multiple models by specifying its region, distribution and number of objects.

It requires this sdformat pull request.

Known limitations:

  • The objects can collide each other when using a random distribution.
  • There are different alternatives for specifying the position of the models, but nothing is ready to specify orientations.

Open question: The Population class needs a pointer to the world and access to the private rootElement class member. This is required for spawning the models without using the transport. I included Population as a friend class inside the World class but I'm open for suggestions (create a public accessor to rootElement, use the transport for spawning models).

Update: Solved using InsertModelString()

Update: A new tutorial has been created here.

values.description:
Fix SetVelocity for several joints so a World::Step isn't required before calling GetVelocity, doesn't work yet for ODE

Not required for 4.0.0

EDIT: Here's a little more detail; dart and simbody require some extra functions to be called when state is modified (computeForwardKinematics for dart and realize for simbody). I believe it updates a cache of internal variables. See the changes to the regression test to see the effect of this fix.
values.title: Fix SetVelocity for several joints

summary.raw:
Fix SetVelocity for several joints so a World::Step isn't required before calling GetVelocity, doesn't work yet for ODE

Not required for 4.0.0

EDIT: Here's a little more detail; dart and simbody require some extra functions to be called when state is modified (computeForwardKinematics for dart and realize for simbody). I believe it updates a cache of internal variables. See the changes to the regression test to see the effect of this fix.
summary.html:
Fix SetVelocity for several joints so a World::Step isn't required before calling GetVelocity, doesn't work yet for ODE

Not required for 4.0.0

EDIT: Here's a little more detail; dart and simbody require some extra functions to be called when state is modified (computeForwardKinematics for dart and realize for simbody). I believe it updates a cache of internal variables. See the changes to the regression test to see the effect of this fix.

values.description:
By default, the space navigator will control the user camera.

Functionality can be changed in `~/.gazebo/gui.ini`, with

```
#!c++

[spacenav]
deadband_x = 0.1
deadband_y = 0.1
deadband_z = 0.1
deadband_rx = 0.1
deadband_ry = 0.1
deadband_rz = 0.1
topic=~/spacenav/joy
```
values.title: Integrated space navigator joystick

values.description:
Fix for issue #1260.

How to test:

1. Temporarily rename `~/.gazebo`

2. Gazebo with `empty.world` should start right away 

3. You can also disconnect your internet, and gazebo should start right away.

[Jenkins ABI](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-abichecker-precise-amd64/117/)

values.description:
When testing Atlas in drcsim with dart, gazebo would assert at startup due to a problem with DARTPhysics::GetParam (see #1264). This fixes the assert, and adds a test for PhysicsEngine::GetParam to PhysicsEngine_TEST.

As a bonus, I noticed that one of the joint_screw tests is passing with dart, so I enabled it.
values.title: Fix DARTPhysics::GetParam (#1264)

summary.raw:
When testing Atlas in drcsim with dart, gazebo would assert at startup due to a problem with DARTPhysics::GetParam (see #1264). This fixes the assert, and adds a test for PhysicsEngine::GetParam to PhysicsEngine_TEST.

As a bonus, I noticed that one of the joint_screw tests is passing with dart, so I enabled it.
summary.html:
When testing Atlas in drcsim with dart, gazebo would assert at startup due to a problem with DARTPhysics::GetParam (see #1264). This fixes the assert, and adds a test for PhysicsEngine::GetParam to PhysicsEngine_TEST.

As a bonus, I noticed that one of the joint_screw tests is passing with dart, so I enabled it.

values.description:
This pull request allows to clone a simulation by saving the current world's state, spawning a new gzserver, and then, loading the world file in the new server. Some comments:

* To avoid log collisions, a new command line argument is available for specifying the log file name that you want to use. The cloned server uses an alternative log file.

* It is possible to clone the simulation from the GUI under **File->Clone world** or programmatically via messages. Check the gzserver's log to know the URI of the new server.

* There is a new tutorial [here](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/64/how-to-clone-a-simulation-tutorial/diff).

* I created a new example that programmatically creates a server, and then, it clones it.
values.title: Clone a simulation

summary.raw:
This pull request allows to clone a simulation by saving the current world's state, spawning a new gzserver, and then, loading the world file in the new server. Some comments:

* To avoid log collisions, a new command line argument is available for specifying the log file name that you want to use. The cloned server uses an alternative log file.

* It is possible to clone the simulation from the GUI under **File->Clone world** or programmatically via messages. Check the gzserver's log to know the URI of the new server.

* There is a new tutorial [here](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/64/how-to-clone-a-simulation-tutorial/diff).

* I created a new example that programmatically creates a server, and then, it clones it.
summary.html:
This pull request allows to clone a simulation by saving the current world's state, spawning a new gzserver, and then, loading the world file in the new server. Some comments:

  • To avoid log collisions, a new command line argument is available for specifying the log file name that you want to use. The cloned server uses an alternative log file.

  • It is possible to clone the simulation from the GUI under File->Clone world or programmatically via messages. Check the gzserver's log to know the URI of the new server.

  • There is a new tutorial here.

  • I created a new example that programmatically creates a server, and then, it clones it.

values.description:
Plugins are specified in `~/.gazebo/gui.ini` using:

```
[overlay_plugins]
filenames=<colon_separated_list_of_libraries>
```

There are two example plugins: `gui_over_plugin_spawn` and `gui_overlay_plugin_time`. Compile both of these plugins and put them in your `LIBRARY_PATH`. Then modify `gui.ini` to be:

```
[overlay_plugins]
filenames=libgui_example_spawn_widget.so:libgui_example_time_widget.so
```
values.title: Add ability to specify GUI plugins that appear over render window

summary.raw:
Plugins are specified in `~/.gazebo/gui.ini` using:

```
[overlay_plugins]
filenames=<colon_separated_list_of_libraries>
```

There are two example plugins: `gui_over_plugin_spawn` and `gui_overlay_plugin_time`. Compile both of these plugins and put them in your `LIBRARY_PATH`. Then modify `gui.ini` to be:

```
[overlay_plugins]
filenames=libgui_example_spawn_widget.so:libgui_example_time_widget.so
```
summary.html:
Plugins are specified in ~/.gazebo/gui.ini using:

[overlay_plugins]
filenames=<colon_separated_list_of_libraries>

There are two example plugins: gui_over_plugin_spawn and gui_overlay_plugin_time. Compile both of these plugins and put them in your LIBRARY_PATH. Then modify gui.ini to be:

[overlay_plugins]
filenames=libgui_example_spawn_widget.so:libgui_example_time_widget.so

values.description: The gazebo_ros_force plugin in gazebo_ros_pkgs [calls Link::AddTorque](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/indigo-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_force.cpp#L143), which leads to incessant console spam in simbody with drcsim. This removes the console message.
values.title: Remove SimbodyLink::AddTorque console message

summary.raw: The gazebo_ros_force plugin in gazebo_ros_pkgs [calls Link::AddTorque](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/indigo-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_force.cpp#L143), which leads to incessant console spam in simbody with drcsim. This removes the console message.
summary.html: The gazebo_ros_force plugin in gazebo_ros_pkgs calls Link::AddTorque, which leads to incessant console spam in simbody with drcsim. This removes the console message.

values.description:
The `Collision::GetShape` function is not const, which was causing a problem with my attempts to make a workaround for #1265 (in [branch issue_1265](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/branch/issue_1265)).

Here I'm deprecating the non-const version of `Collision::GetShape` and overloading a const version alongside it. ~~I had to make some funky changes to SimbodyPhysics.cc and factory.cc to force it to use the const version and avoid a deprecation warning (now that I'm writing this, would it be better to try to disable the warnings with a pragma instead?).~~ I'm using pragmas in two places to avoid deprecation warnings.

[API/ABI checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-precise-amd64/111/)

[Regular jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/188/) has some unrelated test failures

See pull request #1191 for the merge forward to default
values.title: Make Collision::GetShape a const function

summary.raw:
The `Collision::GetShape` function is not const, which was causing a problem with my attempts to make a workaround for #1265 (in [branch issue_1265](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/branch/issue_1265)).

Here I'm deprecating the non-const version of `Collision::GetShape` and overloading a const version alongside it. ~~I had to make some funky changes to SimbodyPhysics.cc and factory.cc to force it to use the const version and avoid a deprecation warning (now that I'm writing this, would it be better to try to disable the warnings with a pragma instead?).~~ I'm using pragmas in two places to avoid deprecation warnings.

[API/ABI checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-precise-amd64/111/)

[Regular jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/188/) has some unrelated test failures

See pull request #1191 for the merge forward to default
summary.html:
The Collision::GetShape function is not const, which was causing a problem with my attempts to make a workaround for #1265 (in branch issue_1265).

Here I'm deprecating the non-const version of Collision::GetShape and overloading a const version alongside it. I had to make some funky changes to SimbodyPhysics.cc and factory.cc to force it to use the const version and avoid a deprecation warning (now that I'm writing this, would it be better to try to disable the warnings with a pragma instead?). I'm using pragmas in two places to avoid deprecation warnings.

API/ABI checker

Regular jenkins job has some unrelated test failures

See pull request #1191 for the merge forward to default

values.description: There are still some issues with detecting and using an external copy of libccd instead of gazebo_ccd.  This PR fixes some inconsistencies and allows for the detection and use of an external libccd.
values.title: Fix external libccd detection

summary.raw: There are still some issues with detecting and using an external copy of libccd instead of gazebo_ccd.  This PR fixes some inconsistencies and allows for the detection and use of an external libccd.
summary.html: There are still some issues with detecting and using an external copy of libccd instead of gazebo_ccd. This PR fixes some inconsistencies and allows for the detection and use of an external libccd.

values.description: `Collision::GetShapeType` was non-const, so I added a const version in pull request #1189 and deprecated the non-const version. This pull request is a merge of that branch forward to default, removing the deprecated version of the function.
values.title: Make Collision::GetShapeType const (default branch)

summary.raw: `Collision::GetShapeType` was non-const, so I added a const version in pull request #1189 and deprecated the non-const version. This pull request is a merge of that branch forward to default, removing the deprecated version of the function.
summary.html: Collision::GetShapeType was non-const, so I added a const version in pull request #1189 and deprecated the non-const version. This pull request is a merge of that branch forward to default, removing the deprecated version of the function.

values.description:
Made this change because Windows has an easier time with zip files.

Example usage:

`gzprop ~/.gazebo/models/ground_plane/model.sdf`

Try uploading the resulting zip to [the propshop](http://thepropshop.org/upload).
values.title: Update gzprop to output zip files.

summary.raw:

values.description:
This is a new math class called SignalStats that computes incremental statistics on signals (see [gazebo_design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/default/signal_stats/signal_stats.md) for more detail). I used this extensively for the accuracy tests and refined the API to minimize the lines of code required for implementation. I think it can be useful in integration tests as well and have converted the `INTEGRATION_physics_inertia_ratio` test as an example. It's especially useful in reducing console spam by replacing expectations inside of loops with a single expectation outside the loop.

I will make a separate pull request to ignition-math.
values.title: New math class SignalStats

summary.raw:

I used this extensively for the accuracy tests and refined the API to minimize the lines of code required for implementation. I think it can be useful in integration tests as well and have converted the `INTEGRATION_physics_inertia_ratio` test as an example. It's especially useful in reducing console spam by replacing expectations inside of loops with a single expectation outside the loop.

I will make a separate pull request to ignition-math.

This is a new math class called SignalStats that computes incremental statistics on signals (see gazebo_design document for more detail). I used this extensively for the accuracy tests and refined the API to minimize the lines of code required for implementation. I think it can be useful in integration tests as well and have converted the INTEGRATION_physics_inertia_ratio test as an example. values.description:
As detailed in #1081 and #1194, the data returned by certain bullet API's is sometimes off by one time-step. I've made workarounds in Gazebo. I should file these as upstream bugs as well, but I haven't had a chance to show how to reproduce them outside of Gazebo. I'll cc @erwincoumans now and file an upstream issue later.

I made these fixes for the physics accuracy tests.

Also, these are a few of the fixes, but I believe there is still a universal joint test that fails as well, so this isn't a complete fix.
values.title: Partial fixes for bullet off-by-one timestep (#1194, #1081)

summary.raw:

I made these fixes for the physics accuracy tests.

Also, these are a few of the fixes, but I believe there is still a universal joint test that fails as well, so this isn't a complete fix.
